FRIDAY, MARCH 31, 1905.
The Customs Administration's statistics for
the trade of Egypt during the past year have
just been issued. There returns show an enormous
expansion in the volume of trade, which is greater than that of 1903 by more than one
and quarter million starling in exports and
nearly font millions sterling in imports. Were we- to consider the figures of the gold coin imported (over £7,600,000) and exported (over £2,730,000) the total increase would be found to be enormous.

Such trade statistics, of course, constitute only one of the indications of the great wave of prosperity that is passing over the country. All other criteria point unmistakably to the same conclusion. Banking and other capital from foreign sources is pouring into Egypt; a new Limited liability company appears almost daily, the price of land, both for agricultural and building purposes, has risen enormously Egyp­tian securities on the local and foreign market stand at quotations which dam the con­fidence of investors in the future develop­ment of the country, and large blocks of them have been taken off the. foreign markets by purchasers in Egypt; the revenues increase notwithstanding continual reductions in taxa­tion ; the population, both native and foreign, is waxing in numbers and in wealth, and the standard of comfort of the former is ruing year by year.

In another column we have dealt with some aspects of Anglo-Egyptian trade, typical y in regard to the shrinkage of our imports into Egypt. Much has beau said about the want of enterprise of the British merchant as com­pared with his foreign competitor*, and we are compelled to admit here in Egypt, where them are ample opportunities of judging, that a great deal of it is well-founded. Wo are aware that there are certain artificial disadvantages against which British find it extremely difficult to contend, even in a neutral market such as this. Dumping, for instance, will account for some of the loss of trade in steel and cotton yam. But dumping will not serve to explain the successful com­petition of our rivals in certain lines oi cotton fabrics and in numerous less important articles of manufacture.

It is especially to these smaller branches of trade that we should like to direct the attention of our countrymen, fur it is there that trade might be built up to compensate for that which has been lost in the staple articles oi British export, cotton and metal goods/- Although a growing market, Egypt is not an easy one to work in, and its difficulties are apt to deter new-comers from commencing operations. We may state in a few words what a march*, intending business with Egypt must be on pared to do. He will probably have to work.

credit terms, have an agent thoroughly) acquainted with the market, with whom him must keep constantly in touch; his good) must be cheap, and adapted to the taste and needs of the consumer. Our enterprising rival* from Continental countries have been working the market assiduously on these lines for many yean. To the success of their
j efforts the trade returns are sufficient tons of money.

PEACE IN SIGHT,
MR. ROOSELVELT AS MEDIATOR
NEGOTIATIONS PROGRESSING

div.p: The "Tides'' learns from St. Petersburg that Russia and Japan have selected President Roosevelt to act as mediator. Negotiations are. already in progress; An early suspension. Of hostilities, may be expected (Reuter.)
It is understood that Russia has made known to Japan the negative conditions under which she is prepared to negotiate, for peace, namely no cession of territory, and no indemnity.
A -Russian semi-official agency, says the despite the genera inclination in, favor of the conclusion of the war, Russia has not prepared to proposed, peace conditions. (Reuta:)

THE CRETAN QUESTION.
PROCLAMATION BY PRINCE GEORGE.

div.p: Prince George has issued a proclamation notifying the Cretans that the Powers have commanded their troops to restore order but; that he had appealed to them for 86 hours' grace to enable him to warn the insurgents; He, therefore, exhorted them to put down their arms and return home, {Reuter.,
The Emperor- William left. (Reuter.)
The anti-French Clemente meditate a demonstration in favor of Emperor William. (IJarai.)

The Ministerialists held aloof. ®

Accident to HARVEY PASHA.—

A French contemporary states that Harvey Pasha narrowly escaped a serious accident the other day at Dessouk.; A fire had broken out in a house there, and while Harvey Pasha was going .over the building part of a wall gave way and half buried him. Harvey Pasha was extricated froth the debris with some slight bruises

div.head: CRİME AT ASSIOUT. SERIOUS STATE OF THINGS.
div.p: I mentioned in my last correspondence that crime in Assidut was increasing terribly and that this state of things was mainly due to there being something wrong with the police. [I will give two casesia proof of this contention.

Four days ago, a telégram was sent from the Mamour of Abnoub to the Parguet at Assiout saying that a woman's body had been found floating on the Nile near Abnoab. Two hours later, another telegram arrived stating that the body was bruised in many places and that the women must have been murdered before her dead body was thrown into the river. The Mamour, added in this. telegram that the Abnoub doctor was "absent and asked for the Assigut doctor to be sent at once.

Accordingly the doctor, accompanied by the Substitut" of the Parquet, went to Abnoub. But, on their arrival they found, to their great astonishment, that the body had disappeared and there were no traces of it.

On being interrogated the Mamour accused the Moswen of ordering the ghaffits to dispose of the body in the Nile, so that they might not bave an additional crime in their markaz. l'he Monwen in his turn açoused the Mamour. Enquiry is now being made, not about the murder case, but about the responsibility of the Mamour aud Molwen. The President of thre Parquet, the Inspector of the Ministry of the 'Interior, and the Moudir attend the enquiry. Whatever may be the result of their investigation; and whether it be proved that the Mainour. or the Muawen is responsible, the Markaz, as a whole, is the cause of an occur. rence which looks serious enough to come under.dhe head of crime. So it is with policemen in the provinces. A crime is hushed up that the list at the end of the month may appear small, and sometimes & policeman accuses an innocent person because the real perpetrator is unknown.

The second caise I aun going to mention proves the last part of this statement. In my last letter I mentioned the case of the man at Awlad el Sheikh who murdered three men. When he was committed for trial, another was charged with him, he being accused of murdering one and his companion of murdering the other two: The murderer was an onéry. of the Omdoh and the other was a friend of the criminal. The Court after two days' examination found out that he was mnocent, and accordiogly condemned the Omdeh and his mun to six mouths' imprisoniment with hard labour for bearing false witness.

Such is the thạnagement of criminal cases here. The difficulty lies ju the faot that the police official, froin the ghaffirs at the bottom up to nalours at the top, are "responsible" for finding the author- of every crime. They are lifble to a penalty in cases where they cannot find out a criminal. A natural result of this organisation, a by no means small number of innocent people are committed, for trial every day. The results frequently are, firstly, the real criminal escapes punishment and secondly, an innocent person is gondemued. The guilty man finding himself victorious, as he has carried out his criminal intention without being -punished for it, is ensouraged to commit more primes. The second, in his turn, finding that he was unjustly condemned because of false witnasa given against him by omdehş and ghaflirs, makes it his first object on leaving prison to revengo himself, and again more crimes are committed.

Although illustrationg of my statements oocur_ every day, yet the. Mitsistry of the Interior sticke obstinately to its regulations. I-am informed by the local officials here that the Ministry is continually urged by the inspectors to change this vicious system but all to ng effect. I have therefore sent this plain statement of fact 'to, the "Gazette" in order that the supreme authoritió may be made aware of the state of things and obange the present system.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL
div.p: The General Assembly of the Legislative Council will meet at 10a.m. on Monday. H.H. the Khediye will inaugurate the session. The Ministers will be present, and the Khedive, after the usual opening speech, will submit the decree relative to the destruction of the cotton worm to the assembly

On Monday next also, the Legislative Coun: cil will discuss the now regulations concerning the administration of Marsa Matroub, and will note the receipt"of a letter from the Government informing threm that the deoree relating to lotteries has been promulgated in its new form after being approved by the Mixed Courts.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN TRADE
DECLINE IN IMPORTS. STARTLING FIGURES.
div.p: It is a melancholy reflection that while ng land's political influencé in: Egypt is becoming paramount oor imports into the country fail to keep up even a norms, rate of progress, and are growing staller by degrees every year. The returns for 1904, which have just been issued by the Customs Administration, afford little cause for congratulation. During last year the imports into Egypt adyanced by nearly four millions sterling, but the percentage of the United Kingdom in the total import trade of Egypt is slowly but steadily declining and now stands at 8A, as against 35.3 in 1903 and 37.5 in 1902. This logs of trade to the extent of 31 per cent in two years represents something considerably over half a million sterling. In 1899 and 1900 our proportion was 38.6 and we have to go as far béck as 1896 to touch & lower proportion than we did last year, when Great Britain's proportion of imports fell to 32.2, although in 1894. and 1895, the two previous years, it had been as high ag 85.6 and 38. The Castoms returns for 1904 and 1903 give the proportional part of imports contributed by each nation per mille for each category of goods and we will keep to this system in the following comparison.

. 1. Last year England's exports of coal here were | 129,against 146 in 1903, worked iron and steel importa fell from 84 to 72, cotton thread from 27 to 23, carriages (wagons) from 12 to 10, mood for building, eto., from 10 to 6, haberdashery and ironmongery from 9 to 8, and miscellaneous imports. from 174 to 164. The increases OVERY the previgps year are as follows: cotton textures, from 361 to 378, machinery, from 65 to 76, mixed textures, from 46 to 54, copper and. brass, from 84 to 38, woollen and linen yarn, from 18 to 20. Manufactured linen goods remained the same.

Our rivals in the Egyptian import trade, Belgium, Italy, and Germany, all show a oon; siderable advance in 1904 over their share of imports in 1903: Taking 1,000 as the total import from all countries, Germany's imports rose from 44 to 55, Belgium's from 31 to 36, and Italy's from 53 to 67. .
"The attention of the President of the Board of Trade was recently drawn to the persistent shrinkage of British imports to Egypt.

The official reply was that the fluctuations il the figures from year to year "arise, to a large extent, from the variations in the price of coal, the imports, of which are derived almost entirely from the Upited Kingdom. If coal be excluded, the figures will appear as follow

Assuming this to becorrect, the above figures, exclusive of coal, are-by no means encouraging, for even when than Imanipulated they show a shripkage from 1898, whereas our rivals'importa are on the upp krade.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL CO.
div.p: The latest Bolletio of the Suez Canal Com pany contains the following 'announcement:
Des inforinations ont été publiées dans divers journaux sur les intentions du conseil d'administration au sujet de la fixation du dividende de l'exercice 1904, et de ce que es
informations n'ont pas été démenties par la - Compagnie on paralt disposé à conclure à leur exactitude.

Nous rappellerons qu'il n'est pas dans les habitudes de la Compagnie d'infirmer ni de confirmer les nouvelles plus ou moins tendancieuses qui sont répandues sur les questions intéressant les porteurs de ses titres. Nous rappellerons aussi que le conseil n'aura a statuer qu'au mois de mai prochain sur le dividendo à proposer pour l'exercioe 1904. et sur la détaxe qui pourra correspondre 8.00 dividende.

We understand that M. de la Bouglisse has resigned his position on the board of the Ibrahimith Ploughing Company.

div.head: STATE OPERA.:
div.p: A correspondent.writes :-In reference to the petition of the abonnés of the Khedivial Opera House, which is to be sent to the Government protesting against the decision of the Société Artistique to bring over an. Italian opers, company in the season 1905-06, does not the remedy lie in the abonnes' owa Hands: What would be simpler than that they should - refuse in a body to subscribe for the season 1

There is no earthily reason why they should páy for company of whiah they disapprove, and in froe of such a practical' attitude of the abonnds both the Government and the Société Artistique would be helpless, as it is quite impossible to run an opora season on a more subsidy. If the abonnes would not, instead of talk, thoy could easily force the hand of the Société Artistique.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COMPANIES.
div.p: LONDON OPINION.,

The "Pall Mal Gazette" says Can 'the Egyptian mining market but keep itself moder ately blear from scandal and rig and corner, it may easily, command & large thessure of public favor this spring. Some pedle there are, and of them not a few, who mustapacha late 1 yet must speculate in mines or nothing, and these worthy supporters of share-manufacturers are sick unto death of the Kaffir Circus. . The market is out of touch with everybody, having disgusted the public with its inanition, put itself into opeia hostility with the big houses by its attitado upon the double, commission questior, and made no sort of provision for novelties at reasonably low prices, such as the public delight to gamble in. The West Afri can marketis negligible, the Indian mines are not "everybody's money," while the less said about Westralians the better. A now sensation is needed now vehicle for a mining gamble. And if only Egypt can turn out a tey good companies, the market is made. Bat the promotors must have it dinned into them that to give the public no run for their money is to condemn the market's óhances from the outset, and if the same stapid, courses are followed which have landed West Africans and Rhodesians into their present state, the wirepullers will only have themselves to blape. Spécolatora must also remember that even under the most favorable conditions the profitableness of mining in Egypt has still to be demonstrated.
The following appeared in reply to the above :
A correspondent who, as he puts it, is, in common with the majority of the market in

Mummies," extremely anxious that what we referred to on Saturday as "the taint of Kaffir covetousness" shall not spread, and so destroy the present public confidence in new Egyptian issues, writes: "I am sure there is only one feeling about your comments on Saturday with reference to the Egyptian market, and that is one of gratitude. Especially is this so since at the present moment an attempt is being made to introduce in connection with a concern called Egyptian Options (Limited)-abont to be floated-all the most objectionable features of Westralian finanging. The jobbers and financial houses connected with reputable "Mummies" are chagrined, and so might the publio well be, tog, at this development, especially se the Egyptian Government has taken such sorupulous cara to safeguard new Egyptian mining issues from any such tintoward methodhither to. All the vid devices of founderssbares and their manipulatiou for the promoters' inte rest and against that of the public are resurrected by the "Angasta Syndicate' --which is Mr. Waddington and seven signatories of
$1 each-in issuing its now bantling. The I publio can, obtained one foundørs' share if:

they first subscribe for 100 shares cash; but the-Augusta Syudioats' reserves the rights to, or in respect of, 1,750 founders' shares ! For what 1 'Business referred to in the memo randum,' eto. Where is this menoprandum } Why were application forms at out without it? I have seen two to former, but nothing of the latter. Howo-and-corner methods of this sort are calculated to defeat all above board dealings, and to spread the taint you reter. to."

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: ATHLETIC NOTES.

We would remind out readers that the entries for the athletic sports promoted by the Alexandria Amateur Athletio Clab close on Saturday, April 1, so intending compotitors who are not yet members should send in their names for election without delay. Wo hear that the entries are likely to bo moro numerous than last year, though several of last year's runners will not be seen. Sobilizzi, the 1902 champion, will not compete, and Matheson, who put up such a good fight in the pole jump last year, has left the country. His venerable, opponent, however, is with ns still, and though suffering from a football injury, is practising. We hear the B.T.C. ataff have got odt some new athletic blood which wo heartily weloome, In the Veteran's race the favorite has not been discovered, there being three previous winners amongst the entrants. This ought to be a good race, but we would like to see many more of the good-old-have-beens competing. Surely they are not afraid of their ages being caloolated1 from their starts 1 The hurdle -race promises to be more interesting than át recent meetings, there being a fair number of good entries. It is very regrettable that the Earl and Counters of Cromer find it impossible to honor the gathering with their presence.

Tho kon. secretary wishes us to state that members will receive their tiokets and programmes towards the end of next week, or Monday, April 10, at the latest. Should any member not receive them by that dato be would do well to set the hon. secretary.

div.head: AUSTRALIA IN BOYPT AND THE SUDANAS
div.p: As our readers are aware the National - Mutual Life Assodiation of Australasia (Limited) has started an Egypt and Sudan branch in Cairo recently with a local board consisting of Sir Wm. Willoocks and Mr. Henriquer. A meeting was hold at Melbourne on the 20th inst, to receive the report of the investigation into the affairs of the association for the three years ended Sept. 80, 1904. The valuation of the liabilities had been made on the same basis as last time, and a sum of £260,000 was divided among the polioy-holders, showing an increase of £60,000 over the amount divided at Sept. 80, 1901.

div.head: NICE VALLEY BLOCK E."
PROSPECTS OF THE COMPANY- SUBSIDIARIES TO HE FORMED.
div.p: The annual ordinary general mooting of the members of the Nile Valley Block "E," Limit­ed, wo* held in London oN Match 23 under the presidency of Mr. 0. \V. Ramaay (the chairman of the company).

S The Chairman, before proving- the adoption ■ of the report of the directors and the accounts, said 4 few words to »how the protection given to investor in the mining industry of Egypt J Turning to the balance shoot, since the issue (d this report the remaining shares—3,260— had be applied for and issued, thus complet­ing the issue of the entire w of £3.

I hi the HuiigoL concession the' amount expend­ed was for tho exploration of an area of about miles, which comprised a geo­logical survey of ilm area, the locating ol old workings and the sinking of four pits or shafts m.i justify them in boring for coal, which hud been most ably done by Sir. U. U. Carey, who was iu charge. The income and expenditure account was most moderate, and, ho did not think, required comment. With regard to Block 'T.'." when the rirat expedition was sent to this property they sank eight small shafts with a view to locating the reef, but Jound indications at the northern part of the block the more . favorable, and os the capital at their disposal was limited they concentrated the work upon this particular shaft, the results of which were so clearly shown iu the reports of Mr. Norway, and which had been endorsed by the engineers, Messrs. Lake and Currie. The total footage was 1,083 ft. in drives and sinking. They would ob­serve by the plus accompanying the report that they were now driving both north and £9util at the 100 ft. level j also that as they had previewed in depth the reef which they discovered had been improving in value. It was new established that the reef ou Biock "JS" w.is the same fissure as that existing at the Um Garaitut mine, consequently no doubt Would exist in the minds of engineers or others w to the continuity of the reel and its values. He was continued in this by a clause in Mr. Newbury's report—an do rood by Messrs. Luke and Currie— in which ho said that the strike, dip and general appearance at the Lode led to the belief that they wero ou the same fissure as the Nile Valloy Company at Um Uaraiort.

They were much encouraged by tho work that had been done, and ware pushing it for­ward with-all the energy possible. By the courtesy of the Hilo Volley Company they had nada arrangements for irial curbing with the mill of three stamps, which would no utilised in ascertaining alues. They bad also marie an application to that company fur the use of their heavy stamps for bulk samples, and he had no doubt this would be arranged. They hud some 1W tons which they could commence to crash. Hu could not, say how hopeful they were in to. the ultimate value of this mine,: which they wore anxious should bo among the. pioneer mines of Egypt. (Applause.) He read , letter from Mr. It, J. Price, the chairman ol the Nile Valloy Company, who recently visited tho mine, in which ho said he was delighted to Bay that trewsi very much pleased with what he saw-rfEe'reef had a good appearauce, and Mr, Norbury was able to show visible gold. He had a high opinion ol tho prospects of the company, and congratulated them upon their staff at the mine.

With regard to the Dongola Concession, Mr. Carey was dispatched to the concession to locate old workiugs. Tho area was very largo, but in the tint season's work be not only- located several old workings and mode a geo­logical survey of the concession, but also examined the southern part and sunk several small pita or shafts to see if he coaid discover any well-defined coal measures. Diamond drilling was now in progress to try to find a workable seam of coal If one was struck the value would be enormous, and ho believed that their chances wero more than even of doing ho. To confirm this he consulted with Mr. Mills, an eminent coal expert, wlm bad written him & letter, in which ho expressed the belief that coat would be found. (Applause.) This conces­sion wak, .! course, an immensely valuable asset to Block "E,'' and contained great pos­sibilities- Any of the old workings in the north might prove of sufficient value to form hsidiaries; and again in the south, if they ok a workable seam of coal, it would neces- e the formation of a large company. The u-Government hod authorised the capita- jn of a syndicate to more thoroughly .re and develop this concession, with -apital of £100,000, £50,000 of which i-Ji was to he working capital. A financial •tip in London was dosirioue of taking up is concession, and it wae a question with the uirectors whether it would bo better to offer at to the shaicliuldera or complete negotiations with this group. A survey had also been made of the agricultural land bordering tho Nile, in consequence of which an application was made for a-grant of *0,000 acres, The Government . had informed them by cable that they were - willing to grant 25,000 acres, and the remaining 15,000 acres was atiEI under consideration. The Sudan Govermeut were not disponed to grant agricultural land to mining companies; hut, recognising the work the company had done! they had made ihe grant on condition that it should be undertaken by a separate company, 'ihe idea was that there should be a large company, with a capital of £400,000 and a working capital of £250,000, and the directors were in negotiation with a strong group,with a view to taking this up. (Hear, boar.) In con­clusion be thought the facts he had given showed that the Block "K" a»sois must ultimately be of very great value. He mow! the adoption of the report and accounts.
The motion was at once agreed to.
An extraordinary meeting of the company was Utea held, when the Chairman moved the four

resolutions appearing on the notice. The first and second resolutions—increasing the increasing by the creation of 20,000 now shares of £1 each, and directing that 6,000 of such new shares be offered to the members of the company in the proportion of one now share for every five existing share-, were unanimously
Office to.
The Chairman next proposed a resolution approving ihe agreement between the company ami Mr. E. A. Jload guaranteeing the subscri|>- tion of the said 6,000 shares.
On this being pot to the meeting, about 20 voted in favor and 7 against.
Mr. H. J, Ircdale demanded a poll.
The Chairman moved the fourth resolution relating to the directors' control of tho new share.-', and tliia was declared carried by 2t> votes to 5.

Mr, Parker moved the fifth rosolution deal­ing with the remunoniticiii of the di roc tors, and increasing. the amount from £150 to tho chairman ami £100 to each of tho directors per annum to £300 amt £200 respectively.
Mr. Beal seconded the motion, and this was unanimously agreed to.
Subsequently Mr. lredale intimated that, in deference to the views of the majority of shareholders, he would withdrew bis demand for a poll.
A vote of thanks was accorded tho chairman for his lucid speech, and the proceedings then terminated.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN FELLAH
div.p: FOLK SONGS.

A very interesting little collection of folk songs collected at Sakkara by Professor J let "rich Schaefer during the winter of 1900-1, during tile excavations of the Berlin Museum at the. Some -IQ, says the author, were contributed by u black Ibrahim E Sudani, whose family had bean settled in Egypt for some generation*; the remainder weeo mostly contributed by a gbaffir named Mahmoud Molmmod El Etr. The songs are quite short not one exceeds 2'* lines ami porno are simply con plots, while others re­semble the south German 'Sdiuoedor-.nnpll' or the Irish 'Loobeen' in which one or mare of a party sings a verse or couplet which is answered by the rest. Here is on example Question. Ya banat, yalli bctimlu Kir-el-morado kam A nstcer. Asbara min aba la'a
Wabm min takht el-huzam. which being translated goes as follow*
.You girls who are drawing water How much is the rent of tho watering [place 1
AfMPef. Ten ol those with tho window
(i o. sovereigns)
And a kiss under the nose ring.

The majority ol the songs are love songs (war and politic*, have no place in tho collec­tion) and some of them nro ol a high quality, spontaneous, artless, and fail ol deep feeling. "Khabat el iiGWa fil-hab14 is a delightful little verse, but One cannot help regretting that tho songs are so short European folk-songs on an average have more than twoor three Conplotxand there Egyptian songs conttin enough to make a reader certain that the fellab Lai not had all the poetry ground out.of him. The workmen's songs are also interesting and there are two capital stanzas describing tho different recep­tion.-? accorded to tho wearers ol the tarboush and the 'libdV or felt cap. By tho way, we miss tho pleasing chorea ascribed to the peasant poets of the Delta ■—
El mufottish ioglesi gaih Hat el-wiski, hat os-soda !
But perhaps that has not reached Sakkara yet.

div.head: MOHAMEDAN EDUCATION.
div.p: Since he went out to assume- .command ol the farce* in India Viscount Kitchener has seldom spoken in public on non-military oc- carioM, but on March 1 his Excellency pre­sented the prizes to successful students ol the Calcutta Mad roach, and briefly addressed the assembly. He said he could not help feeling that the honor of being invited to take part in tho function was duo to his having been the founder of a similar insti­tution to theirs in Khartoum. They would be glad to learn that the Gordon College there was progressing in a most satisfactory manner and was affording ednoation to a large number of their oo-religiunista It was now apparent that tho hope he expressed when his appeal for funds in England was so generously respouded to, that tho Gordon College would eventually becomo the centre of light and learning for the greater part ol Northern Africa, was no visionary ideal, but was in a fair way of being realised in the near future. Parents in all petitions and classes iu the Sudan wore most an­xious to send their sons to the collage, and ho was pleased to announce that the nu thorities of the institution had decided to add another wing to tho building, sc it* to afford the much-required increased accom modatiun foF students. English men and women gave generously to establish and maintain such institutions as theirs, not merely that geography, history, and wiener might be taught, but to enable the youths Ol Mohamedan races Under our rule to carry out that grand Mohamedan precept, which was also the precept of other religions, that to improve the mind and body was the duty of man to God. The British Government and people did all in tboir power to pay back the debt they owed the East in phi losophy, science, literature, and art by exbs- hifehteg and maintaining such institution". He trusted bi* young auditors would make the knowledge they gained at the Madrasah ft stoppings tone to future study and im­provement,

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
